results.title: How many members in a set
results.creator_credit: D. Keith Carlson and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Kindergarten child series”.
Children are presented with a variety of materials through which to learn mathematical concepts. The teacher invites several children to group small toy cars into various sets and endeavours to lead them to the abstract notion of members of a set. From here the film then moves around the class and observes the activities of other children with the material offered them.

results.title: How level is sea level
results.creator_credit: Larry Klingman and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Defines mean sea level and explains how it is determined. Describes factors that influence sea level at various locations, and analyses the problems of creating a sea level canal in Central America.
results.description: Defines mean sea level and explains how it is determined. Describes factors that influence sea level at various locations, and analyses the problems of creating a sea level canal in Central America.

results.title: How its surface changes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Understanding Our Earth”.
Explains the slow but constant changes in the surface of the earth by showing the erosive effects of water and wind upon a recently excavated mound of raw earth. Includes scenes of the eruption of the Paracutin Volcano, the Grand Canyon of the Colorado River, and a rocky mountainside, pointing out the geologic evidence of forces which continue to build up and wear away the surface of the earth.

results.title: How it happened
results.brief_description: Shows common risks and dangers telephone linesmen face resulting generally from negligence of correct safety procedures on their part or that of their fellow workers. A series of sequences provide examples of accidents brought about by one or more of the following basic causes: thoughtlessness, short cuts, poor job planning and arrangement, negligence of safety rules and over-confidence.

results.title: How insects help us
results.brief_description: A junior social studies film. Develops four ideas about insects: that all are worth observing and learning about; some are helpful; others harmful; and some are beautiful. Behaviour of wasps, ants, bees, flies, grasshoppers and others is studied.

results.creator_credit: Jack Denove, Leon S. Gold and Roundtable Productions

results.title: How fibres are spun
results.brief_description: Shows methods of spinning that were practised before the Industrial Revolution, and so elucidates the basic operations of the mechanical spindle. Shows the opening out and carding of wool and cotton by hand.

results.title: How effective is your reading?
results.brief_description: This film is designed to help students and adults improve their reading skills. Demonstrates methods of faster reading and better understanding, emphasising at the same time the need for practice. Illustrates a number of specific reading skills, including how to read in larger thought groups, to skim, to read when in search of information, and how to read rapidly but at the same time comprehend fully.

results.title: How does a rainbow feel?
results.creator_credit: Donald Wise, Stanley S Madeja and WH Productions
results.brief_description: Shows the variety of aesthetic educational qualities in the environment - sounds, shapes, patterns, colours and textures. Children are seen exploring and discovering such areas as body movement, shapes, points of view, characterisation and dramatic plot. In the final minutes of the film, a class of primary school children create a dramatic plot about a young boy with a violin named the “Rainbow King”. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: How does a candle burn?
results.brief_description: Demonstrates how the properties of candle wax change as the wax is transformed from a solid to a gaseous state and explores the nature and shape of the flame and the function of the wick.
